word.entryDescription: You say Wow! to show you are surprised or very happy
word.entryExample: Wow! This is really the most beautiful room in this flat.

word.entryDescription: (of skin/cloth) with small lines and folds
word.entryExample: She turned round and I saw her wrinkled face with a gentle smile and blue eyes.

word.entryDescription: the part of the body where your hand joins your arm
word.entryExample: He's sprained his wrist playing football.

word.entryDescription: to put language into a form that can be read, such as by pen on paper, by keyboard onto a computer screen, etc
word.entryExample: I'm writing a letter to my friend.

word.entryDescription: to write something again
word.entryExample: You have to write out your work right from the beginning.

word.entryDescription: to write something in a full and complete form, often using notes that you made earlier
word.entryExample: Sandra had to write up her English essay on her laptop.

word.entryDescription: not correct
word.entryExample: I'm sorry, that's the wrong answer.

word.entryDescription: a photograph taken or examination made using radiation that can pass through the body showing the things inside it
word.entryExample: I don't think it's broken but have an X-ray to be sure.

word.entryDescription: a comfortable boat with sails and often an engine, which is used for pleasure or sport
word.entryExample: I'd like to sail on a yacht around the islands.

word.entryDescription: a period of 12 months, particularly one that runs from January through to December
word.entryExample: The beginning of the year is January 1st.

word.entryDescription: something that is yellow, is the colour of a lemon
word.entryExample: There are lots of yellow ducks on the farm.

word.entryDescription: on the day before today
word.entryExample: Where were you yesterday?

word.entryDescription: a thick slightly sour liquid made from milk
word.entryExample: He used to have yoghurt with the main meal.

word.entryDescription: not very old
word.entryExample: Jill is too young to go out by herself.

word.entryDescription: an expression used to end a formal letter
word.entryExample: Write 'Yours faithfully' if you wrote 'Dear Sir/Madam' at the start of the letter.

word.entryDescription: an expression used to end a formal letter
word.entryExample: Write 'Yours truly' in professional correspondence when you write to a client by his name, but sign the letter in the name of the firm.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to the person being spoken or written to, affected by an action when that person also performs the action
word.entryExample: What have you done to yourself?

word.entryDescription: a place where young people who are travelling, can stay very cheaply for a short time
word.entryExample: She works as a receptionist at the youth hostel.

word.entryDescription: young or seeming younger than you are
word.entryExample: He is 64 but his optimism has kept him youthful.

word.entryDescription: a kind of traditional tent, used e.g. in Mongolia
word.entryExample: I live in a yurt, which is a kind of round tent made on a strong wooden frame.

word.entryDescription: an African animal like a horse with black and white stripes
word.entryExample: Look, there's a zebra next to the trees.

word.entryDescription: a thin line of metal or plastic teeth which you use to fasten clothes
word.entryExample: I'm returning these trousers because the zip doesn't work!

word.entryDescription: (= postcode) a series of letters and numbers used as part of an address when you send something by post
word.entryExample: What is your zipcode, please?

word.entryDescription: a place where you can go to see animals
word.entryExample: Was the zoo very interesting?

word.entryDescription: a scientist who studies zoology (a study of animals and their behaviour)
word.entryExample: Rainforests give zoologists, botanists and biologists the opportunity to do research.
